thoughts.a: The input and output grids are the same sizes. The input grid is mostly a black color background along with a few scattered objects. There are two single tile colors, one aqua and one yellow. There are also two single tile wide paths, one green and one pink, each of them with one 90 degree turn in them. We notice that one of the legs of each path lines up with, or is in the same row or column as, one of the single tiles. For example, the green path lines up with the aqua tile, and the pink path lines up with the yellow tile. In the output grid, we see something very similar to the input grid, but the paths have moved to encounter the single tiles that they were lined up with. Additionally, the tiles that were previously occupied by the path are now the same color as the color of the single tile for each path. Effectively, this looks like a type of snake game, where the paths represent a snake that is going after single tiles, pulling behind itself in the same location as the previous tiles in the path. However in this case, the old path that is displaced by the movement is replaced not with the background color but instead by the color of the single tile that that particular snake is going for. Thus the hypothesis is the following. The input grid will contain a mostly background color, probably black. There will also be some number of snake-like paths, and some number of single tiles of differing colors. Each snake-like path will be aligned with one of the single tiles, such that the snake-like path could move in a straight line and would intersect with it. In order to construct the output grid, we need to effectively move the snake-like paths forward until they intersect with their aligned single tiles, and also change the color of all the tiles that are displaced by this movement with the color of the single aligned tile, instead of the background color. The output grid is the same size as the input grid, and all other tiles stay the same, including the rest of the background and the original location of the single tiles.
thoughts.b: The input grid is a mostly black color background along with a few scattered objects. There are two single tile colors, one pink and one red. There are also two single tile wide snake-like paths, one yellow and one blue. Each of the snake-like paths are aligned with a single color tile, where one of the ends of the snake-like paths would intersect with a single color tile via a straight line. In this case, the yellow path is aligned with the red tile, and the blue path is aligned with the pink tile. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to make the snake-like paths move forward in a straight line until they intersect with their aligned single tiles, and also change the color of the tiles that are displaced by this movement with the color of the single aligned tile. In this case, the yellow snake-like path will move six tiles to the right to just intersect the red tile, which means that when the rest of the yellow path moves along with it, the end of the yellow path will displace itself by six tiles, and those six tiles need to now be red. Similarly, the blue snake-like path will need to move five total tiles to the left to intersect with the pink tile, and so the end of the blue path will displace itself by five tiles, and those five tiles will need to be replaced by pink tiles. The rest of the output grid stays the same. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.c: The input grid is a mostly black color background along with a few scattered objects. There are two single tiles, one pink and one aqua. There are also two single-tile wide snake-like paths, one yellow and one green. Each of the snake-like paths are aligned with a single color tile, where one of the ends of the snake-like paths would intersect with a single color tile via a straight line. In this case, the yellow path is aligned with the pink tile and the green path is aligned with the aqua tile. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to make the snake-like paths move forward in a straight line until they intersect with their aligned single tiles, and also change the color of the tiles that are displaced by this movement with the color of the single aligned tile. In this case, the yellow snake-like path will move three tiles up to just intersect the pink tile, which means that when the rest of the yellow path moves along with it, traversing the previous path of that object, similar to a snake, then the end of the yellow path will displace itself by three tiles. Those three displaced tiles should be pink instead of the background color of black. Similarly, the green snake-like path will need to move six total tiles to the right to intersect the aqua tile, and so the end of the green path will displace itself by six tiles, and those six tiles will need to be replaced by six aqua tiles. The rest of the output grid stays the same. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid the hypothesis holds.
